Hoja1.title: Antic Teatre
Hoja1.adress: Carrer de Verdaguer i Callís, 12, 08003 Barcelona
Hoja1.summary: The beer garden after the show is really nice and filled with people, hard to find a table but I had a lot of fun.

Hoja1.title: Walk through the Gothic Quarter
Hoja1.adress:
The Gothic Quarter
Barri Gotic
Barcelona
Hoja1.summary:
As you walk out of El Borne from the Picasso Museum and slowly make your way through the rustic streets of the Gothic quarter, you feel the history resonating from it's narrow lanes. 

This quarter encompasses the oldest parts of the city of Barcelona, and includes the remains of the city's Roman wall and several notable medieval landmarks. Much of the present-day fabric of the quarter, however, dates to the 19th and early 20th centuries.

Hoja1.itinerary_title: Family Fun at Costa Dorada PortAventura Theme Park

Hoja1.title: Casa Battlo
Hoja1.summary: Make your way through the labyrinth of Gotico to Passeig de Gracia, a grand boulevard home to two of Gaudi's most iconic structures. Start here, with Casa Battlo, a radiant turquoise marvel whose undulant curves suggest the rippling currents of the sea.

Hoja1.title: Montserrat Hike
Hoja1.adress: Monistrol de Montserrat Train Station, 18, Carrer Pont, 18, 08691, Barcelona
Hoja1.summary:
Once you arrive to Monistrol de Montserrat train station, you have to find the beginning of the trail before making your way up the mountain. It takes aproximately 15 minutes and there are guided signs to lead the way. 

Once you make it to the track, it's a steady incline on a rocky terrain with some random stairs all the way to the top. There are red, white and green painted markers all the way up to the monastery, and various forks in the path you can take. I would recommend following the Cami de les Aigues (GR 5) trail, it veers slightly to the left and is the easiest option. It takes you 10 minutes longer to get to the top and ascends less quickly, but has a wider and easier path. 

The hike takes between an hour and a half to two hours depending on how fast a hiker you are and which paths you choose to take.

Hoja1.title: Sangria on rooftop bar 'La Dolce Vitae' on Hotel Majestic
Parc de la Cuitadella/ Arc de Triomph
Hoja1.summary: The Parc de la Ciutadella is beautiful and contains the city's zoo, the Palau del Parlament de Catalunya, a small lake, museums and a large fountain designed by Josep Fontserè. Climb towards the Arc de Triomphe, the triumphal arch of the city. It was built, by the architect Josep Vilaseca i Casanovas, as the main access door for the 1888 Barcelona World Fair. After this, go through El Borne and pay attention to the various parts of street art that are they scatter through the streets.

Hoja1.title: Lunch at Taller Tapas
Hoja1.summary: Nice tapas, staff were great with the kids, especially when they found out it was my sons birthday.

Hoja1.title: Brandenburg Gate Museum
Hoja1.summary: The Brandenburg Gate Museum is a multimedia history museum with a panoramic wall. Very interesting and worth a visit.

Hoja1.title: The Wall Museum
Hoja1.summary: Worth a visit after walking along the East Side Gallery, it helped us understand the gravity of the situation and is really eye opening to the history.

Hoja1.title: Restaurant 212
Hoja1.summary: Affordable and extremely tasty menu from former michelin star chef of Bord'eau. I was worried it would be a bit fancy to bring the kids, but actually it was quite casual and the staff were very patient and considerate.

Hoja1.title: Amsterdam's 17th Century Canal Belt
Hoja1.summary: Amsterdam’s 17th-century canal belt curves around its city centre and is within easy walking distance from de Oude Kerk.
